Fabrizio Romano reports that Brighton & Hove Albion verbally agreed with the Italian club on a deal worth an initial £15million with around £2million in add-ons. Formal steps will now reputedly follow for the Ecuador international to sign.
Barcelona's option to sign Marcus Rashford is said to be as low as £26million.
The Athletic claims he has also taken a pay cut to facilitate a move. Rashford will reportedly miss out on between 15 per cent and 25 per cent of his current salary, depending on multiple factors.
United are said to have made a loan offer for Emiliano Martinez.

The Daily Mail claims Aston Villa turned down the bid immediately, and officials from the club were reportedly incredulous at the prospect of such a deal. They are said to value their goalkeeper in the region of £40million.
Man United will sign an important striker this summer, claims Fabrizio Romano.

The journalist reiterated that in his latest YouTube video. He also says Rasmus Hojlund prioritises staying at United and fighting for his place unless Ruben Amorim tells the player he doesn't trust him anymore and has to go.
United not offering Victor Lindelof a new contract reportedly hurt their chances of signing Viktor Gyokeres this summer.

Portuguese sports newspaper Record claims that Hasan Cetinkaya, both players' representative, was upset with United letting Lindelof go. Reputedly, that is why 'the door has been closed' to any Ruben Amorim reunion.
Intermediaries close to Sporting CP have again offered United the opportunity to bid for Viktor Gyokeres.

Fabrizio Romano claims in his latest YouTube video that the offer from Sporting's side came overnight. Gyokeres, though, only wants Arsenal and United do not intend to make a bid for the Sweden international.
Bryan Mbeumo is finally a Manchester United player. This summer's transfer saga is finally over with the club confirming they have signed the forward last night.
Attention now turns to a striker. United have no intention of making an offer for Viktor Gyokeres, but there are links to Benjamin Sesko.
That is it for our Manchester United transfer news blog this evening, where the Reds have, at least, confirmed the blockbuster arrival of Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford!
Stay tuned for more updates tomorrow...

Manchester United are NOT expected to make a bid for Chelsea forward Nicolas Jackson, it has been claimed. The 24-year-old has emerged as a potential transfer target for United, as Ruben Amorim tries to strengthen his attack.

Reports claimed on Sunday that United have held talks with Jackson's representative Ali Barat over a potential blockbuster move to Old Trafford. The Senegal international scored 13 times and grabbed six assists in 37 appearances for the Blues during the 2024/25 season.

However, he appeared to drop down the pecking order at the Club World Cup following his red card against Flamengo and the double arrival of Liam Delap and Joao Pedro. Indeed, after returning from suspension, Jackson played just 30 minutes in Chelsea's four knockout fixtures.

Speculation has since increased around Jackson's future at Stamford Bridge, with United expressing an interest and holding talks with his agent. But the Reds are not anticipated to make an offer for the ex-Villarreal man, according to journalist Ben Jacobs. It's added that a lot would have to change for that to alter in the coming weeks.

Chelsea made a late bid to attempt to hijack Manchester United's move for Bryan Mbeumo, according to the Daily Mail. The Reds confirmed the £65million arrival of the 25-year-old from Brentford on Monday.
But before United got the deal across the line, Chelsea made a last-ditch attempt to try and convince Mbeumo to make the move to Stamford Bridge instead, lodging a fresh proposal.
Brentford director of football Phil Giles has heaped praise on Bryan Mbeumo after the 25-year-old forward made the move to Manchester United.

In a statement on Brentford's website, Giles said: "On behalf of everyone at Brentford, I would like to wish Bryan all the best for the future and thank him for his fantastic efforts over six seasons with us," said director of football Phil Giles.

"Bryan came to us as a teenager, and it has been an absolute pleasure for all of us here to watch him develop as a player and a person. Our fans have loved him, and he has been a part of some of our greatest days.
"There is always a right time for a player to move on and, for Bryan, that time is now. He has the opportunity to go to one of the biggest clubs in the world, and we are very happy for him.
"Bryan will always be welcome back at the Gtech. We look forward to seeing him in September and whenever our paths cross in the future."
Bryan Mbeumo has spoken for the first time since his move to Manchester United was confirmed on Monday night.

Mbeumo told the club's website: "As soon as I knew there was a chance to join Manchester United, I had to take the opportunity to sign for the club of my dreams; the team whose shirt I wore growing up.

"My mentality is to always be better than I was yesterday. I know that I have the spirit and character to reach another level here learning from Ruben Amorim and playing alongside world-class players. "Everybody told me about the environment that is being created here and how exciting the plans are for the future. This is a massive club, with an incredible stadium and amazing fans, we are all really determined to challenge for the biggest trophies."

Manchester United have confirmed the signing of Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford. Mbeumo has signed a five-year contract, with the option of an additional year, at Old Trafford. The 25-year-old joins for a fee of £65million, plus £6m in add-ons based on team and individual performance.

The forward has signed in time to join his new teammates on the pre-season tour of the USA. United are set to travel across the Atlantic on Tuesday and will play West Ham, Bournemouth and Everton in the Premier League Summer Series in New Jersey, Chicago and Atlanta.
Read the full story here.
Manchester United are ready to approach Aston Villa about a potential move for Emiliano Martinez, as they look to solve their goalkeeping situation following Andre Onana's latest injury blow.
Onana is expected to miss the start of the Premier League season after injuring his hamstring during pre-season training. Indeed, United's hunt for a new goalkeeper has increased.
While Martinez is suspended for the first game of the season following his red card at Old Trafford in May, United are keen to sign the Argentine and make him their latest summer addition.

In fact, according to the Daily Mail, United held discussions over the weekend about signing the 32-year-old. Although Villa value Martinez at £40million, the Reds are still expected to make an approach.
Manchester United are willing to repeat the deal they have made for Marcus Rashford to part ways with Rasmus Hojlund in the summer transfer window.
Hojlund showed signs of promise in his first season in the Premier League but the 2024/25 campaign proved to be a difficult one for the Dane as he managed just four goals in 32 appearances.
Ruben Amorim has gone on record to state that he is looking to improve United's goalscoring threat, while the 22-year-old is adamant that he is staying at Old Trafford this summer.
However, interest in the striker remains high in Italy, particularly with Inter Milan. Hojlund still has high stock in Serie A thanks to his performances for Atalanta prior to his move to United.
According to Calciomercato, United are now willing to loan Hojlund out this summer in a similar deal to the one which they have agreed with Barcelona for Rashford's exit.
Read the full story here.
Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim has spoken to Porto goalkeeper Diogo Costa about a potential move for him this summer.
According to TransferFeed, Porto want £43.3million plus add-ons to be included in a possible deal for Portugal international Costa.
While Emiliano Martinez is considered as United's main 'keeper target, Costa is right near the top of their shopping list.
According to TEAMTalk, Atletico Madrid are interested in signing Manchester United forward Antony during the summer transfer window.
Diego Simeone's side are in the market for a wide forward addition and Antony is one of the names on Atletico's shortlist ahead of the 2025/26 season.
Real Betis remain keen on re-signing the Brazilian after he scored nine goals and provided five assists in 26 matches during a loan spell in the second half of last season.
Chelsea are 'looking at' making a move for Manchester United's Alejandro Garnacho, as they attempt to strengthen their forward line, according to football.london.
Enzo Maresca's side want to add at least one more winger to their squad after losing Noni Madueke to Arsenal, and Garnacho is right at the top of their shopping list.
Alongside the Argentine, RB Leipzig's Xavi Simons, Aston Villa's Morgan Rogers and Juventus superstar Kenan Yildiz are among the others that Chelsea are considering.

Manchester United are eyeing up a move for Sporting CP midfielder Morten Hjulmand, according to A Bola. Sporting are aware that Ruben Amorim is very fond of the Denmark midfielder, who has other admirers in England, including Manchester City.
United are looking to strengthen their midfield and Hjulmand is someone that is being considered by Amorim. The 26-year-old made 47 appearances for Sporting last season.
According to The Mirror, the Portuguese boss wants to bring in two more signings this summer.
While signing a new striker remains the club's priority, the report also notes interest in adding a midfielder.
United have so far signed Matheus Cunha from Wolves and are close to announcing the arrival of Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford.
Royal Antwerp goalkeeper Senne Lammens has already admitted he would find it difficult to turn down a move to Man United.

Lammens, who kept 10 clean sheets for Antwerp last season, was linked with United earlier this year and was asked about the prospect of a move to Old Trafford at the time, admitting he would have to give serious consideration to the prospect of moving to M16.

"Wow, [it's] hard to say," Lammens told GVA back in February. "I've only played one full season at Antwerp. If something comes along that I can hardly say no to and that will benefit the club, I'll have to think about it seriously. But if I'm the first 'keeper here for another year, that's no problem.

"The first time I heard it, I thought. 'Wow, a world team that follows you. That is special'. Of course, I was also spoken to about it a lot and when I made a save in training, it was United this, United that. Funny, I would do it the other way around too. But you can't dwell on it for too long. They are still just rumours.

"Those top clubs have so many scouts and follow so many players. So it doesn't have to mean anything yet. It will only become clear in the summer whether anything comes of it. But of course it's only positive. Especially because it's the best competition in the world and my profile – my stature and way of playing – is similar to English football.
"You have to physically hold your own there and that suits me. You do follow the teams that follow you a little bit, but it's not like I'm watching entire matches. Summaries are enough."
The former Man United star believes his old club is losing a 'great' player by allowing Rashford to join Barcelona.
Speaking to YouTuberIShowSpeed, Pogba said: "That's crazy, but I'm happy or him because they took his number. Manchester United are losing a great player, unlucky for them.

"It's great for Barcelona to be honest. I'm not even talking about United, because they've bought a few new players and the new manager wants to do his thing I guess. It's not really his fault, if he doesn't believe in someone. He needs to win. If he doesn't win they're going to sack him."
Manchester United have no intention of making an offer for Gyokeres, MEN Sport understands.
Ruben Amorim worked with Gyokeres during his time at Sporting but United have not made an offer to sign the Sweden international and do not intend to submit a bid.

Gyokeres looks destined to sign for Arsenal. Mikel Arteta's side have finished runners-up in the Premier League for three successive seasons and signing a prolific striker has been their main aim this summer.
According to Sky Germany's Florian Plettenberg, Jackson remains a candidate to reinfoce Man United's attack this summer.

Plettenberg said: "Benjamin Sesko is a player who says, 'Okay, if there is not the right offer this summer, I can also imagine staying at RB Leipzig.' But there are also now many, many movements in the background, and there are also talks with interested clubs to our clear understanding that Manchester United is targeting him.

"He's one of two or three candidates as a new number nine striker for United. Then the other one is Nicolas Jackson. I cannot close the door for a possible Chelsea interest. Let's see what will happen in the next two or three weeks with Benjamin Sesko ahead."
Man United have tried to hijack a move for Viktor Gyokeres from Arsenal as the transfer saga continues.

The Gunners have been in talks with the Portuguese side for some time and were optimistic about finalising a deal before their pre-season tour to Singapore. However, Sporting president Frederico Varandas has remained firm on his valuation of the Swedish player.
Meanwhile, United have stayed alert to the situation, and when complications arose between Arsenal and Sporting, the Reds attempted to sign the Swedish goalscorer.
That said, MEN Sport brings you the latest updates on Gyokeres from Portugal.
Galatasaray have reportedly reached an agreement with Napoli to sign Man United-linked Victor Osimhen on a permanent deal.

While United are believed to be interested in signing a striker this summer, the deal taking Osimhen to Galatasaray removes one of the options they had available. United have seen their options further limited with the news that Sporting's Viktor Gyokeres looks almost certain to join top-flight rivals Arsenal.

It is said that a €75million (around £70m) transfer fee will be paid in two instalments, including a down payment. The report claims that the two clubs have agreed to a €40m (£35m) upfront payment and €35m (£30m) in instalments to be paid until July 2026.
The issues are at the back and up front. United have prioritised their attack over the goalkeeper and the timing of Andre Onana's injury could work in his favour ahead of the September 1 deadline.

The more pressing matter is the striker. With Joshua Zirkzee back in Manchester nursing a minor injury, Rasmus Hojlund did not even start against Leeds United. Amorim picked a rotational XI that was demonstrably not the strongest available to him, with two auxiliary centre backs in the back three and rookie Diego Leon in from the start.
After Mbeumo, it's understood that a goalkeeper and striker will be prioritised by Man United.
And according to Fabrizio Romano, the Reds have made initial contact with Royal Antwerp to request information about their conditions for a potential deal to sign Senne Lammens.
Sunday was a strange one with Viktor Gyokeres. Reports in Portugal claimed that United had made an approach for the striker which was higher than the fee Arsenal are said to be willing to pay.
However, that was then swiftly played down by the likes of Fabrizio Romano and Ben Jacobs. He is still expected to join Arsenal.

headline: 'Really excited' - Manchester United sent message after loan signing completed
body: Shrewsbury Town director of football Micky Moore is "really excited" to have completed the signing of Manchester United goalkeeper Elyh Harrison.
The 19-year-old has joined the League Two side on a season-long loan deal, marking his first loan spell in professional football.
Harrison, who joined United's academy from Stevenage in 2022, spent the first half of last season on loan at non-league outfit Chester, keeping seven clean sheets in 18 appearances.
He was due to spend the duration of the 2024/25 campaign at the National League North outfit, but United recalled him in January to train with the first-team and feature for the academy.
He was named on the bench eight times by Ruben Amorim after being recalled.
After showing plenty of potential at youth level, United have now decided the next step in Harrison's development is for him to get regular game time in the EFL for the first time.

Addressing the addition of the young goalkeeper, Moore told Shrewsbury's club website: "I'm really excited that we've signed Elyh. He's someone we've targeted since last season ended and I think he's got a bright future.

"We watched him play at Chester last year and continued to watch him when he went back to play for United's under-21s. We think he's got all the right characteristics and that this could be a very good loan for him.
"Michael [Appleton] wanted to get him in the building as soon as possible, so I'm really happy to get it over the line because it was a tough process due to the amount of interest in the player.
"But I want to thank Elyh and Man United for their help throughout. I'm excited to see how he develops throughout the season."
Manchester United have launched their new away kit for the 2025/26 season, inspired by the club's early-1990s Adidas snowflake kit.

headline: Jurgen Klopp has made Benjamin Sesko feelings clear as Man United know transfer fee
body: Former Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp described reported Manchester United target Benjamin Sesko as a "ridiculous" talent with an "incredible skillset" as the forward continues to be linked with a switch to Old Trafford.
The 22-year-old has been linked with a move to the Reds over the weekend, with The Athletic reporting that United have "kept tabs on" the forward for more than six years.

However, at this moment in time, it is claimed that the Slovenian international is not the "subject of serious attention" from Ruben Amorim's side, who are in the hunt for a forward after missing out Liam Delap as well as seeing speculation around Hugo Ekitike and Viktor Gyokeres come to nothing.
Since signing up to Red Bull's multi-club model in 2019, Sesko has gone from strength to strength and established himself as one of the brightest young forwards in Europe.

In 2023, after four years at Red Bull Salzburg, the 22-year-old joined RB Leipzig in a deal worth roughly £20million, having rejected United when the planned move was announced a year earlier, while his agent has since paid multiple visits to Old Trafford and Carrington.

In the years since signing for the Bundesliga outfit, the 22-year-old has scored 27 goals in 64 league appearances in Germany, resulting in him regularly being linked with a move to the Premier League. Leipzig would consider a fee of around £70m for the forward.
And earlier this year, former Liverpool manager Klopp, now the Head of Global Soccer at Red Bull, was effusive in his praise of Sesko.

"I’ve actually known him for a while, I knew him already when he was at Salzburg. I think we played a friendly game here when he was very, very young," recalled Klopp in January. "I was really impressed, I thought, “Where do they get all these players? Ridiculous.’
"I have no plans with him, just to make that clear. Don’t get it wrong, I will not show up in training and tell them what to do.
"Our plan, and I don’t have to ask Marco Rose what his plan is with him [Sesko], I know it… he wants to help him score as many goals as possible.
"He has space for improvement, space for development, incredible skillset, incredible potential, so I’m happy that we have him."
Sesko is under contract at Leipzig until 2029, having renewed his terms last summer.

headline: LUCKHURST: Manchester United are the biggest winners in Marcus Rashford deal after Barcelona changed their mind
body: Back in January, the word from Barcelona was that the club’s sporting director, Deco, was “not that fussed” about Marcus Rashford.
Rashford ended up playing in a different shade of claret and blue at Aston Villa, underwhelmed and has now ended up at Barcelona.

It is a move that does not make much sense yet also makes sense. Barcelona have a deluxe back-up to a front three of Raphinha, Lamine Yamal and Robert Lewandowski. Manchester United have found a club prepared to cover Rashford’s £325,000-a-week salary. It was always going to be a loan with an option to buy.

Barca have admired Rashford for several years yet are signing him at one of his lowest ebbs. Villa declined the chance to buy him for £40million, Rashford had his squad number revoked and was ordered to report at United’s Carrington training complex after the first team had left this month.

An agency source said Rashford has “done extremely well” to get Barcelona. The Spanish agent, Arturo Canales, helped broker Rashford’s loan to Villa in February and was re-hired to specifically secure a move to Barcelona.

United have done extremely well to get Rashford off the books before August. Liverpool merit a mention. They resisted selling Luis Diaz to Barca after their prime target, Inaki Williams, signed a new contract with Athletic Bilbao. Rashford is Barca’s plan C and, on paper, a substitute for La Liga's champions. He has broken double figures in only one of the past four seasons for United.

High-ranking figures at United expected him to move abroad. Rashford mischievously refused to discount crossing the divide to Manchester City or heading down the East Lancs Road to Liverpool. There was no concrete evidence either of United’s rivals were interested in him.

It is in United’s interests that Rashford performs in Spain. It would make him more sellable next year, when he will have entered the final two years of his United contract. While Ruben Amorim is in situ, there is no chance of United reintegrating Rashford back into their first team squad.

Rashford has put in the hours over the summer. His Instagram account, almost certainly run by his brother and former agent, Dwaine, has charted a rigorous training schedule of gym-work and ball-work. Rashford spent four hours in a Salford gym last Monday.

Hangers-on weighed Rashford down in recent years but his entourage on holiday in Cannes were on the grass with him. He was joined by brothers Dwaine, Dane, cousin Lois and former United academy teammate Roshaun Williams.

Rashford shone at Camp Nou in United's engrossing 2-2 Europa League knockout draw in February 2023, scoring their equaliser and single-handedly forcing Jules Kounde's own goal. He was at his zenith that season, with the caveat that Rashford's form came with his camp in the midst of contract negotiations.
Have a glance at Rashford's goals tallies over the past four seasons: five, 30, eight and seven. You can pinpoint the one that preceded a lucrative salary hike.

Despite that 30-goal season, privately he bristled at some of Erik ten Hag's methods and how dogmatic the Dutchman could be. Their working relationship disintegrated during Ten Hag's final year at United.

Rashford was irritated to start the 2023-24 season up front while Rasmus Hojlund recovered from a stress fracture of the back. At Villa, Unai Emery regularly played Rashford through the middle. Lewandowski, 37, is not showing many signs of slowing down but he is out of contract at Barcelona next year.

After Amorim discounted Rashford from selection, the player exercised some moderate PR, attending a game in his hospitality box at Old Trafford. There was polite applause from the Stretford End on his final squad appearance when he warmed up against Newcastle in December.

Figures at United are continuing to tread on eggshells with Rashford, still keen to highlight his legacy as one of their most striking academy graduates. Rashford has long since abandoned diplomacy, thanking Alejandro Garnacho for his puerile post in a Villa 'Rashford 9' shirt last month.

One down, three to go for United. Jadon Sancho, Antony and Garnacho will, by hook or by crook, be gone by 7pm on September 1. United will then have a leaner, fresher and more harmonious forward line. One that has to be sharpened by a new striker.
They need to be fussed about that.

headline: RAILSTON: United must arrange four more exits after Marcus Rashford departure
body: "Yeah, for sure. Everybody in the world wants to play with the best. Hopefully... We'll see."
Those words came from Marcus Rashford last month when a Spanish influencer asked whether he would like to play with supremely talented Barcelona teenager Lamine Yamal.

Rashford has been fluttering his eyelashes at Barcelona, and he will realise his goal of playing for the Catalan club. Manchester United have agreed to send Rashford on loan for the 2025/2026 season and Barcelona will cover his entire wage packet throughout his stay at Camp Nou.

The 27-year-old was one of five players who were told to delay their returns to Carrington after each expressed a desire to leave. United have arranged Rashford's exit with favourable terms and now must address the futures of Alejandro Garnacho, Antony, Jadon Sancho, and Tyrell Malacia to offset incomings.

United have not sold Rashford on a permanent deal, but removing one of the highest earners from the books is a boost, and Barcelona are expected to trigger their option to sign him at the end of the season.

It feels inevitable Rashford will show enough for Barcelona to activate their option to sign him. He may well impress and pundits will then doubtless suggest United made a mistake by allowing him to leave.
The script with Rashford over the next 12 months at Barcelona is predictable, but it will be a surprise if he can sustain strong performances across successive seasons in Spain.
United's attention now turns to the four other players on the naughty step. Garnacho retains the highest value and arranging his sale will unlock much-needed funds for Ruben Amorim.
An initial £127.5million has been splashed on Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo, so selling Garnacho is now at the top of the transfer agenda.
Chelsea and Napoli were interested during the January transfer window. The winger's agent attended a game at Stamford Bridge and told the world he was there by posting on social media.

The suggestion is that Garnacho would prefer to remain in the Premier League, but United will try to offload him to the highest bidder because. They should be trying to get £50million-plus for a player who has proven himself in the Premier League and still has considerable upside. The only problem is potential suitors know Amorim wants rid.
Antony deserves credit for creating a market for himself. The Brazilian was utterly hopeless in Manchester but looked a completely new player during his loan with Real Betis last season.
If you pretend his £86m transfer to United never happened, Antony would look like a decent prospect and a permanent move to a European club is on the cards for him this summer.
United must sell Antony for £32.8m to avoid making a PSR loss. The club will also look to negotiate a permanent deal for Jadon Sancho and the Italian press claim Juventus are advancing.

Juventus will be asked to cough up a fee for Sancho, although United will get peanuts from the last player of the out-of-favour-five, Tyrell Malacia, who looked unconvincing during his PSV loan last term.

The nightmare scenario was that all five players would still be at Old Trafford near the end of the window, but United have shifted Rashford and it's hoped the floodgates will now open for the other exits.

headline: Ruben Amorim has four games to decide on a new Manchester United partnership
body: One down, four to go. Manchester United kicked off their pre-season schedule with a 0-0 draw against Leeds United in Stockholm on Saturday.

For those who watched from either inside the Strawberry Arena or on MUTV, it is unlikely it will be remembered very fondly. In typical pre-season fashion, the game was light on quality and highlights.

United will hope to serve up something a little bit better when they face West Ham United at the MetLife Stadium in New Jersey this weekend in their opening game of the Premier League Summer Series. The Reds fly out to the US on Tuesday and will spend the best part of a fortnight on the other side of the Atlantic.
Their pre-season tour will feature friendlies against Premier League counterparts West Ham, Bournemouth and Everton. Each game will represent an opportunity for head coach Ruben Amorim to experiment.

By the time United return to England and prepare for their final friendly of the summer - a clash with Fiorentina at Old Trafford on August 9 - Amorim will almost certainly have an idea in his mind of what his strongest starting XI looks like.
United face Arsenal in their Premier League at Old Trafford on August 17 and will be determined to hit the ground running after last season's struggles.

Although there is still just under a month to go until their Premier League curtain-raiser, some places in Amorim's starting XI are already nailed down. The likes of Leny Yoro, Patrick Dorgu, Bruno Fernandes, Mathes Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo will all believe they are guaranteed starters.
Occupants of other positions within the XI remain to be decided, with United's four remaining friendlies set to dictate Amorim's thinking.

The Portuguese chief's decision to start Fernandes in the middle of midfield for the draw with Leeds felt particularly telling. Following the addition of Cunha, the feeling throughout the summer has been that Fernandes will start the new campaign in midfield.

Cunha operated as the left-sided No.10 in Stockholm and Toby Collyer, much to everyone's surprise, started as the right-sided No.10. Mbemo and Amad will be the leading contenders to occupy that role come mid-August.

Casemiro and Fernandes started alongside each other in midfield in Stockholm before Kobbie Mainoo and Manuel Ugarte were partnered together for the second half. United were better after the break and Mainoo was a bright spark.
Amorim struggled to determine Mainoo's best position last season, tasking him as either a No.8 or as one of the playmakers. On Saturday's evidence, Mainoo looks more than comfortable in midfield.

However, he was playing alongside Ugarte, who is a defensive specialist, meaning the England international had the freedom to get forward and be adventurous with the ball. If he starts the season next to Fernandes, he will not have that luxury amid the latter's hunger to attack.

To ensure United, who still want to sign a midfielder this summer, strike the right balance in the engine room, Ugarte and Fernandes look the best partnership on paper. Ugarte is an excellent ball-winner and his qualities compliment Fernandes.

Mainoo, though, will believe he has lost time to make up for after a stop-start 2024/25 campaign. However, the prospect of him and Fernandes working side-by-side could leave United vulnerable and potentially exposed in the middle.
Casemiro returned for pre-season looking leaner and fitter, meaning he will be refusing to give up hope of becoming a regular starter this season.
The three US friendlies and the clash with Fiorentina in M16 next month could settle this conundrum for Amorim.
Manchester United have launched their new away kit for the 2025/26 season, inspired by the club's early-1990s Adidas snowflake kit.

headline: RAILSTON: Why Manchester United will not care about criticism of Bryan Mbeumo deal
body: After a month of negotiations, Manchester United have officially signed Bryan Mbeumo.
The transfer has been a long time coming and fans were relieved to see the announcement on Monday, which confirmed the £65million signing, with a further £6m potentially due in add-ons.
Mbeumo has signed a five-year contract with the option of another year, and the forward will travel to the United States on Tuesday with his new teammates for the pre-season tour.
It was important to complete a deal in time for Mbeumo to feature in the US and United got the transfer over the line in the end, despite discussions with Brentford dragging on.
Some fans were concerned when Mbeumo had not signed in time for the opening pre-season friendly against Leeds in Stockholm, but that game was essentially a training exercise.
It wouldn't have made much difference if Mbeumo had travelled to Sweden last weekend, although it was obvious why United wanted him to arrive ahead of their trip across the Atlantic.

The USA tour will provide Amorim with the opportunity to intensely work with his players across the next fortnight. The Reds boss will hope to lay the foundations for a successful campaign while in the States.
Mbeumo needed to be a part of that, partly because he needs to adapt and partly because discussions rumbling on for any longer could have forced United to finally walk away from the player.
United have received some flak for taking so long to sign Mbeumo. However, he will feature in America, which is a huge positive, and it was important that the structure of the deal was deemed fair.

Brentford will receive the fee they wanted from the start, but United did not surrender to their demands immediately, submitting two unsuccessful bids before a breakthrough, and negotiating a favourable deal structure.
The London club held the aces during talks. Mbeumo had entered the final year of his contract, but Brentford had the option of extending by 12-months, which helped their bargaining power.
The player indicated his desire to move to Manchester, though, which has been key during the transfer saga over the last month. He desperately wanted a summer switch to United.
The Cameroon international completed his medical over the weekend and was pictured in a suit at Carrington - appearances go a long way and Mbeumo has already made a good first impression.

Rival fans have questioned the transfer fee, but they only need to look at the market for home truths. Anthony Elanga (six goals) signed for Newcastle in a £50m deal, Chelsea signed Jamie Gittens (12 goals) from Borussia Dortmund for £51.5m and Noni Madueke (11 goals) signed for Arsenal for £48.5m.
Mbeumo scored 20 goals in the Premier League - his statistics weren't inflated by cup competitions - and also contributed eight assists, so the initial £65m fee seems like fair market value.
United will be delighted with Mbeumo's arrival and he should be a superb addition.

headline: Brentford statement speaks volumes as Bryan Mbeumo completes Man United transfer
body: Bryan Mbeumo is ‘always welcome back’ at Brentford after completing his eagerly-awaited transfer to Manchester United.
Mbeumo has put pen to paper on a five-year contract at Old Trafford, with a further year’s option. United have paid an initial fee of £65million for the forward, plus a potential £6m in add-ons.

Negotiations with Brentford have gone on for several weeks, with Mbeumo having been United’s priority target after the £62.5m signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolverhampton Wanderers. Mbeumo has arrived in time to join his new teammates on the club’s tour of the USA.

The Cameroon international scored 70 goals and made 51 assists in 242 appearances for Brentford and his departure comes as a huge blow to the London club under four weeks until the start of the Premier League season.
But the Bees say they are ‘very happy’ to see Mbeumo join ‘one of the biggest clubs in the world’ in a highly complimentary statement issued on Monday night.

“On behalf of everyone at Brentford, I would like to wish Bryan all the best for the future and thank him for his fantastic efforts over six seasons with us," Brentford’s director of football Phil Giles told the club website.

“Bryan came to us as a teenager, and it has been an absolute pleasure for all of us here to watch him develop as a player and a person. Our fans have loved him, and he has been a part of some of our greatest days.
“There is always a right time for a player to move on and, for Bryan, that time is now. He has the opportunity to go to one of the biggest clubs in the world, and we are very happy for him.
“Bryan will always be welcome back at the Gtech. We look forward to seeing him in September and whenever our paths cross in the future.”
Mbeumo joined Brentford from French side Troyes in 2019. He has become the club's record sale after scoring 20 top-flight goals last term, plus eight assists.
Mbeumo said: “As soon as I knew there was a chance to join Manchester United, I had to take the opportunity to sign for the club of my dreams; the team whose shirt I wore growing up.

“My mentality is to always be better than I was yesterday. I know that I have the spirit and character to reach another level here learning from Ruben Amorim and playing alongside world-class players. “Everybody told me about the environment that is being created here and how exciting the plans are for the future. This is a massive club, with an incredible stadium and amazing fans, we are all really determined to challenge for the biggest trophies.”
Manchester United have launched their new away kit for the 2025/26 season, inspired by the club's early-1990s Adidas snowflake kit.

headline: LUCKHURST: The moment Matheus Cunha showed he is Manchester United material
body: Just like last year, Manchester United's pre-season schedile began without them scoring. Unlike that unwatchable friendly against Rosenborg, they avoided defeat to Leeds United in Stockholm.
Ruben Amorim fielded two different XIs in each half as the United players build up match fitness ahead of next Saturday's first tour test against West Ham United in New Jersey.

Overall, 24 players were used as Tyler Fredricson and Jack Fletcher emerged for minutes in the second half. United fly to Chicago, their base while they are in the United States, on Tuesday and should have Bryan Mbeumo on board their flight.
Here are five talking points from their first friendly in Sweden:
Each player will be at different stages of their fitness and the rotational XI indicated that. The second XI for the second half was arguably stronger.
It was still mystifying that Amorim opted for Toby Collyer as one of the two playmakers when it is the one area of the squad where United have a surfeit of options.

Collyer said on tour last season he needed to improve on his ball-work. Shifting from a deep role to such an advanced position for a central midfielder by trade is unlikely to do him any favours. Collyer looked as lost as a playmaker as he did at left back against Barnsley last year.

Midfield is one of United's weakest areas. The brains trust possibly believe they can cope with a quintet of Collyer, Bruno Fernandes, Manuel Ugarte, Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo in a season devoid of European football. United cannot shift Casemiro, which is partly blocking an upgrade to that department.

Fernandes has excelled from deep in the past and United are banking on him to carry the midfield. Ugarte was dropped for the Europa League final, Mainoo lost his first-team status several months ago, Casemiro could be redundant with no UEFA competition to participate in and Collyer has started three games against teams from League One, Scotland and Romania.
Mainoo lined up in midfield in the second half and Amorim has to make his mind up on where he will primarily play next season.
Shortly before the hour, Diogo Dalot charged into the Leeds third and played the ball into the channel for Rasmus Hojlund. Hojlund may have strayed offside and nothing came of his backheel.
Before Hojlund got back to his feet, he was ready to let rip at Dalot. "F**k's sake," he shouted, clearly irked that Dalot had not passed the ball sooner.

It is not the first time Hojlund has vented at Dalot's end product. The most infamous flashpoint was in San Sebastian in March. Dalot was apologetic that night. On this occasion, he kept on running and blanked out the noise from Hojlund.

Amad is the one winger who has survived United's cull as he has the defensive discipline to complement his attacking instincts. He has never been a problem for United, either, unlike Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Jadon Sancho and Antony.
Amorim said he prefers to use the Ivory Coast winger closer to goal but he played Amad on the flank in Sweden. Bryan Mbeumo is waiting in the wings and time will tell if he is used on the wing.

Matheus Cunha was fouled a couple of times on his first United start and one or two other challenges arguably warranted a stoppage. Cunha got plenty of attention at Wolves and markers will doubtless be tighter and nastier now he is United's No.10.

Fernandes was quick to impose himself on his United debut in February 2020 and Cunha is not a shrinking violet. He was well within his rights to rebuke Chido Obi for shooting while off balance when Cunha was well poised to at least hit the target as the ball rolled towards him. Obi offered an apologetic low-five.
Even from 45 minutes that may have sent plenty of viewers to sleep, there were glimpses that Cunha is United material.
Sean Longstaff and Daniel James lined up together for United. Leeds United. If Ole Gunnar Solskjaer had it his way, it would have been for Manchester United six years ago.

United's pursuit of Longstaff ended in 2019 when Newcastle quoted them £50million. James did join the club and he has regressed to his true level since that purple patch at the beginning of his Old Trafford career, signing for relegation fodder, suffering relegation and a couple of seasons in the Championship.

headline: RAILSTON: Amad gives honest verdict on Marcus Rashford leaving Manchester United
body: Manchester United forward Amad has wished Marcus Rashford good luck ahead of his move to Barcelona.
United are close to agreeing a season-long loan deal for Rashford with Barcelona. The Catalan club will cover all of the 27-year-old's wages and have the option to sign the forward permanently.

Rashford was left in Manchester - he has been training away from the main group at Carrington - while Ruben Amorim oversaw United's opening pre-season friendly of the summer against Leeds on Saturday.
The relationship between Amorim and Rashford became frosty in mid-December when the academy graduate was dropped from the squad for the Manchester derby at the Etihad.
Rashford has been looking for a new club this summer, along with Alejandro Garnacho, Antony, Jadon Sancho, Antony and Tyrell Malacia, and he will get his dream move to Barcelona.

After the 0-0 draw against Leeds, Amad walked through the mixed zone at the Strawberry Arena and briefly shared his thoughts on Rashford's impending departure to Barcelona. "Well, the only thing I can say is good luck to him, but I’m more focused on United and my team," said Amad.
Amad is close friends with Garnacho, who is also expected to leave this summer, and he was asked whether it would a shame to see the winger depart, considering their relationship.

"I think this is not really my problem," said Amad in a thoughtful tone. "The only thing I’m thinking right now is how we will learn together as a team and yeah, that’s the only thing I’m trying to think about right now."
Amad has regularly shared photos with Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo from within the dressing room at Old Trafford. The trio are understood to be particularly close.

Garnacho attracted interest from Napoli and Chelsea in the January transfer window, and the outright sale of the 21-year-old would be hugely beneficial to United to comply with Profit and Sustainability Rules (PSR).

headline: Ruben Amorim hinted at his long-term plan with surprise Manchester United tactic vs Leeds
body: Manchester United supporters could have been forgiven for forgetting all about Toby Collyer ahead of Saturday's goalless draw against Leeds United at the Strawberry Arena in Stockholm.
His place in the XI for United's pre-season opener in the Swedish capital marked his first start of any kind since January 30.

United beat FCSB 2-0 in their final Europa League league phase match that evening and Collyer had been withdrawn by the time goals from Diogo Dalot and Kobbie Mainoo steered the Reds safely through to the last-16.
He was deployed alongside Bruno Fernandes in midfield in Bucharest, with Christian Eriksen and Mainoo preferred in the two No.10 positions.

When the teamsheet dropped at the Strawberry Arena, it appeared as though Collyer was going to operate next to Casemiro in the centre of midfield, with Fernandes supporting new signing Matheus Cunha and Chido Obi in attack.
However, it was Collyer who was deployed further forward. He occupied the right-sided No.10 spot and Fernandes joined Casemiro in the engine room.
Pre-season is all about experimenting ahead of the competitive action so Ruben Amorim is entitled to test the water in matches where the outcome means very little.

However, the United head coach's decision to deploy Collyer further forward was perhaps his way of trying to help Fernandes. Following the addition of Cunha, the feeling throughout the summer has been that the United captain will start the 2025/26 campaign in midfield.
Fernandes regularly dropped deep in the second half of last season and was arguably more effective. He enjoyed a real purple patch in March when he was stationed as one of the two No.8s.

With Bryan Mbeumo closing in on a move to Old Trafford, he is set to battle it out with Amad to land the right-sided No.10 spot. It is unlikely Amorim considers that position as Collyer's long-term habitat.
Widely considered as a midfielder that tends to sit deep and try and marshal proceedings, it would be a drastic shift if he was to suddenly be transformed into a playmaker.

With four more friendlies still to come, Amorim has plenty of time to experiment. However, the closer United get to the end of their pre-season schedule, the more likely it is the former Sporting Lisbon boss will field an XI that resembles something close to the one he has in mind for the season opener against Arsenal.

United's starting XI in Stockholm had a rotational feel to it. As interesting as Amorim's decision to start Collyer in such an advanced role was, it is likely he did it to try and get another look at Fernandes as a No.8.
Having previously admitting he could see himself dropping deeper as his career progresses, Fernandes might be about to make a permanent position change at Old Trafford.

headline: RAILSTON: Amad joking and Leny Yoro smiling - what happened after Manchester United's pre-season friendly
body: Amad, Leny Yoro, Patrick Dorgu, Matthijs de Ligt and Toby Collyer took time to speak to journalists as they left the Strawberry Arena on Saturday afternoon.
Manchester United drew 0-0 with Leeds in their opening pre-season friendly of the summer. The game was essentially about getting minutes into players' legs ahead of the United States tour.

Ruben Amorim didn't speak to the media after the game, aside from MUTV. Erik ten Hag did after facing Rosenborg in Norway and facing Rangers in Edinburgh last summer, but Amorim will speak to journalists when he travels to the States.
Amorim walked briskly through the mixed zone towards the team bus, following Casemiro out of the stadium.

The mixed zone at Old Trafford is makeshift, which means players are brought out to speak to journalists. But the idea is that players walk through the area as they leave the stadium, which gives the media a chance to politely ask if they would answer few questions.
The Strawberry Arena has a 'proper' mixed zone and Amad briefly touched on the futures of Marcus Rashford and Alejandro Garnacho, who are both set to leave the club this summer.

He was also asked about which position he prefers. Amad started at right wing-back against Leeds, but he's capable of playing in the No.10 role in Amorim's system. "I think I have to adapt in every moment and every situation," he said.

"No matter where I play, if the manager wants me to play as a right wing-back or a number 10, then I’m here to help the team. I have no problems with one position, I have no preference. I can play anywhere where the manager wants me."
Amad was one of the only players to emerge with credit from last season.

"I think they [fans] have to be patient with us," he said. "There’s a new manager, with new players and new tactics, so we know last season wasn’t really good for the team, but I think this season we will win a lot with him.

"I hope this season we are going to achieve a lot of good things by the end of the season. Honestly, I can’t say how long it will take, but what I can say is every player will give their best in training and try to do their best, also in the game."
So, what could be considered a good campaign in 2025/2026?
"A good season will be top five," Amad said. "I hope we can achieve that top five at the end of the season because I think they [fans] deserve it."
Amad also revealed what Amorim said in the dressing room. "I think the manager was trying to say something positive to try to say they need to be relaxed and play their football," he said.
"That’s their message and on the pitch, the players have to give everything. Everyone is with the manager and trying to follow his system."

Yoro chatted in French with a reporter and clearly appreciated communicating in his mother tongue. It's understandable that players are more likely to speak with reporters who can speak their language.
Bendito Mantato was congratulated after his first appearance for the first team. Most in the mixed zone wouldn't know Mantato, but he's got a bright future and his profile could increase on tour.

headline: Winners and losers from Man United's stalemate with Leeds as Cunha shines and wonderkid hint dropped
body: Manchester United opened their pre-season campaign with a goalless draw with Leeds United in Sweden.
The game failed to spark but was a chance for United players to get minutes into their legs ahead of their tour of the USA next week.

It also saw Mathues Cunha and Diego Leon make their first appearances since their summer arrivals. Both showed what they can offer during their 45-minute outings and United will hope to have Bryan Mbeumo through the door in the next 48 hours ahead of their flight to the States on Tuesday.
That trip brings three more matches but here's the winners and losers from the stalemate with Leeds.
Matheus Cunha

Made his first appearance in a United shirt and caught the eye with his ability and vision as well as his driving runs and direct threat. Bodes well for the campaign ahead and what the forward can offer.
Tom Heaton

Arguably United's best player. He made a couple of impressive saves in the second half and certainly offered the thought that he could be United's number two ahead of Altay Bayindir. Heaton will hope for more opportunities in the States with Andre Onana yet to feature owing to injury.
Bendito Mantato

The 17-year-old is highly thought of at Old Trafford and of all the youngsters, it was the winger who Amorim handed a shirt to when he rang the changes at the break. Mantato played 35 minutes before being replaced by Jack Fletcher and will hope to earn further chances over the coming weeks.
Mason Mount

It's been a case of 'what if' for Mount at United. Highly regarded by Amorim, injuries have stopped him getting any rhythm since his arrival from Chelsea in 2023. He offered some incision in the second half in Sweden and served a reminder that he still has something to offer this side.
Kobbie Mainoo

Another who played his part in an improved second half showing from United. The midfielder has struggled to nail down a place in the first XI since Amorim's arrival but operated in the pivot position against Leeds and caught the eye. A year ago the midfielder was part of an England squad that nearly won the European Championships, he will hope to hit similar highs for club and country in the upcoming campaign.
Casemiro

Part of the first half XI and the midfielder struggled to impose himself on the contest. His best performances last term were in Europe and with no continental football on offer this season, it's hard to see the Brazilian gets regular minutes. That school of thought will not have altered based on his showing in Scandinavia.
Rasmus Hojlund

Was omitted from the XI in favour of Chido Obi and while we cannot read too much into that given it's the first game of pre-season, the Dane has work to do to convince United he can lead their line this term.

On a couple of occasions against Leeds he could have held the ball up better and with United still searching for a striker, Hojlund knows he has to take every opportunity that comes his way. He didn't quite do that in Stockholm.

headline: RAILSTON: 'I hope' - Amad reacts to Manchester United agreeing Bryan Mbeumo transfer
body: Amad is excited to play alongside Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha at Manchester United.
After protracted negotiations, United submitted a third bid worth £65million plus £5m in add-ons for Mbeumo and Brentford accepted the proposal for the Cameroon international.
Mbeumo is set to undergo a medical and will join United on the USA pre-season tour.

The forward will further strengthen Ruben Amorim's attacking options following the arrival of Matheus Cunha from Wolves. Cunha made his debut for United in the opening pre-season friendly of the summer against Leeds on Saturday and showed glimpses of his quality.
United scored just 44 goals in the Premier League last season and adding fresh blood to the attacking unit was a priority for Amorim, who is also expected to sign a striker this summer.

Amad, speaking to journalists after facing Leeds, said when asked if he was looking forward to playing with Mbeumo: "Of course. We need good players in the team who can bring something to the final third.
"We are really excited to have them in the team and I hope all together we can give something to the fans at the end of the season because they deserve it."
On Cunha Amad added: "He’s a good player, we need good players in the team and he will bring a lot to the team. So I hope he can give us some things different.
"Especially last season, we missed a lot of good players in the final third. He [Cunha] is a good, good player, he scored a lot of goals last season, so I can just wish him all the best."
United, Arsenal, Tottenham and Newcastle were all linked with a deal for Mbeumo this summer, but the player indicated he wanted a move to Old Trafford at the beginning of the window.
Cunha and Mbeumo scored 35 goals between them in the top-flight last season.

headline: Brentford ‘expected’ to make latest move for England U21 star after Man Utd Mbuemo deal confirmed
body: Brentford are expected to resume their interest in Ipswich Town’s Omari Hutchinson after Bryan Mbeumo’s move to Man Utd was confirmed.
With an extra £65m in the bank, Brentford are free to go back in for the England U21 star having seen a bid rejected by the Suffolk club last week.

Hutchinson, who joined Ipswich from Chelsea on loan in 2023 before a permanent deal last summer, had a £35m release clause in his contract, but Brentford’s bid failed to offer that amount upfront. That clause has since expired, meaning Ipswich can demand whatever fee they like.
Despite missing out the first time, Brentford boss Keith Andrews, who played for Ipswich in 2011, remains keen on signing the 21-year-old.
According to Football Insider, sources have said Brentford are “expected” to make another approach in the coming days but the fee is likely to be more than the original £35m release clause.

Having played in the U21 Euros this summer, Hutchinson did not travel with Ipswich to Austria for their pre-season training camp but manager Kieran McKenna was asked about the future of the playmaker.
The Northern Irishman said interest was “natural” but Hutchinson is “still an Ipswich Town player.”
“Omari’s having a well-earned holiday,” said McKenna. “There’s obviously been interested parties in Omari, which is natural with what he’s done. But he’s still an Ipswich Town player.
“My full focus really has been on the group that’s here. Hopefully, we’ll catch up with Omari next week.”
Having come through the Arsenal and Chelsea youth academies, Hutchinson joined Ipswich on a loan deal in July 2023 and was a key part of the Tractor Boys’ return to the Premier League.
His performances, which saw him score 10 and assist six in 44 league appearances, prompted Ipswich to sign him for a then-club record fee of £20m.
But Hutchinson, along with the whole of the Ipswich team, struggled back in the top flight and he managed just five goal contributions in 31 league matches as Town were relegated straight back down.
This summer, he played a starring role in England’s retention of the U21 Euros, scoring a goal in the final as the Young Lions defeated Germany 3-2.

headline: The 20 most expensive forwards ever: Hilarious transfer flops in the top five as Cunha, Mbeumo enter
body: Manchester City are prominent in a list of the 20 most expensive forwards in transfer history. Cunha and Mbeumo are in but No 1) will never be shifted

1) Neymar – £200m/€222m (Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain, August 2017)
A fee so ridiculous La Liga refused to receive the payment so PSG said LOL to FFP and handed the money straight to Barcelona, activating one of those stratospheric release clauses designed to typically make such transfers essentially impossible.

2) Eden Hazard – £143m/€160m (Chelsea to Real Madrid, July 2019)
The initial payment of £88.5m alone would have been a disastrous transfer, but Hazard accidentally activated enough variables in between numerous injuries before his retirement to make this an all-time great waste of money.

3) Philippe Coutinho – £142m/€160m (Liverpool to Barcelona, January 2018)
It’s difficult to pinpoint the most damning aspect of this deal from a buyer’s perspective, but it’s somewhere between the £106m initial fee, the £26.4m in clauses paid out for Coutinho’s first 90 appearances, the £89m premium Barcelona reluctantly agreed to pay if they signed any further Liverpool players in the next two years, the fact Coutinho won the Champions League with Bayern Munich while on loan from the Nou Camp, scoring twice in the 8-2 quarter-final humiliation of the Catalans, or the knockdown price of £17m paid by Aston Villa after four underwhelming years.

4) Ousmane Dembele – £135m/€147m (Borussia Dortmund to Barcelona, August 2017)
With a bruised ego and the Neymar cash burning a hole in their back pocket, Barcelona had tried all summer to sign Coutinho but after facing resistance from Liverpool, they went cap in hand to Dortmund for their back-up instead. And lessons were learned with a £369.6m release clause inserted this time – not that the Frenchman has ever come close to warranting such lavish interest until he found his ambipedal feet at PSG.

5) Joao Felix – £113m/€126m (Benfica to Atletico Madrid, July 2019)
Perhaps the worst match of player and manager there has ever been for a club-record transfer. How strange that the skilful individualist forward who doesn’t track back never meshed with a totalitarian coach who demands suffering and sacrifice from his subordinates. How strange that Atletico committed such sums on a teenager with 45 career first-team appearances. How strange that they couldn’t find anyone to buy him until Chelsea rocked up again.

6) Antoine Griezmann – £107m/€120m (Atletico Madrid to Barcelona, July 2019)
After The Decision favoured Atletico in 2018, the Frenchman could no longer avoid the Barcelona pull a year later in a sale which enraged Los Rojiblancos, considering a £180m release clause had only expired a couple of weeks before. Griezmann has somehow managed to remain without a La Liga winner’s medal through it all, timing his moves back and forth to Atletico and Barca comedically poorly.

7) Jack Grealish – £100m/€117.5m (Aston Villa to Manchester City, August 2021)
While it looked like an ungainly fit at first, Grealish went an awfully long way towards justifying his astronomical fee as a key part of a Treble-winning, mass-celebrating machine in his second season at the Etihad. Then it all started to fall apart again as he lost his way.

8) Neymar – £86.3m/€100m (Paris Saint-Germain to Al-Hilal, August 2023)
That world-record, market-breaking move to France delivered neither the Ballon d’Or nor the non-Barcelona Champions League that Neymar craved, so the Brazilian decided to cheat by joining the most successful side in AFC Champions League history for loadsa money, loadsa cars, loadsa bedrooms and loadsa saunas. A ruptured knee ligament meant he played seven times in Saudi Arabia before being released by mutual consent.

9) Gareth Bale – £85.2m/€100m (Tottenham to Real Madrid, September 2013)
After cramming half of his total Premier League goals by that point into a single phenomenal season, Bale became the latest obsession of a Real Madrid side desperate to win La Decima. The Welshman helped deliver that in his first campaign with a decisive goal in the Champions League final – the first of five European Cups and second of 15 trophies for a player the supporters nevertheless came to hate.

10) Antony – £82m/€95m (Ajax to Man Utd, September 2022)
Erik ten Hag put all his eggs in the Antony basket but a few must have cracked in transit from Amsterdam, the relatively slow and predominantly one-footed winger scoring eight goals and assisting three in a 44-game debut season.

11) Jadon Sancho – £73m/€85m (Borussia Dortmund to Man Utd, July 2021)
In his three full seasons with Borussia Dortmund, Sancho’s least productive campaign was his first, when he scored 13 goals and provided 20 assists in 43 games. Across an entire Man Utd career which still technically remains a live thing after Chelsea paid £5m to return him rather than £25m to sign him, the forward has scored 12 goals and assisted six in 83 games.

12) Nicolas Pepe – £72m/€80m (Lille to Arsenal, August 2019)
After offering the closest challenge to Kylian Mbappe for the Ligue Un Golden Boot, Arsenal spent what was a club-record fee on a player who has popped up around France, Turkey and Spain since being long outgrown by the upwardly mobile Gunners.

13) Neymar – £71.5m/€86.2m (Santos to Barcelona, June 2013)
The financial details are wonderfully murky but official documents submitted to the authority revealed the final fee, as well as a €40m payment to Neymar’s parents.

14) Kai Havertz – £71m/€80m (Bayer Leverkusen to Chelsea, September 2020)
Expensive flop who never fit into one defined position and suffered for regular managerial upheaval? Or scorer of the winning goals in the Champions League and Club World Cup finals? A little from column A, a little from column B.

15) Bryan Mbeumo – £65m/€75m (Brentford to Manchester United, July 2025)
It is a quite significant overpay by some market value standards but ultimately Manchester United believe Mbeumo can help sort out a failing attack after scoring 70 goals and assisting 51 in six seasons at Brentford.

16) Julian Alvarez – £64m/€75.8m (Manchester City to Atletico Madrid, August 2024)
The fee could rise to £80m but eyebrows were raised when Manchester City squeezed quite so much out of Atletico, even for a world champion with 54 goal contributions and six trophies in 103 appearances. A 29-goal debut season in Spain made it seem more as though the Premier League side had been fleeced.

17) James Rodriguez – £63m/€80m (Monaco to Real Madrid, July 2014)
A proper throwback transfer pretty much solely down to Rodriguez starring at the World Cup, the Colombian won a fair few trinkets at the Bernabeu but never came close to settling or justifying that fee.

18) Matheus Cunha – £62.5m/€74.2m (Wolves to Man Utd, June 2025)
In a welcome sign they are returning to a formerly successful transfer policy, Manchester United chucked a whole load of money at a team below them in the Premier League’s bottom half by virtue of goal difference alone.

19) Kai Havertz – £62m/€71.7m (Chelsea to Arsenal, June 2023)
Mikel Arteta saw enough in those three mixed years at Stamford Bridge to deem Havertz crucial to his Arsenal process. Almost no-one else thought it was a signing worth making but the vision has become clearer over time, particularly so in the German’s injury-enforced absence.

20) Mykhaylo Mudryk – £62m/€70m (Shakhtar Donetsk to Chelsea, January 2023)
The biggest possible fee is the one most often quoted but Chelsea would be absolutely delighted if they end up paying the full £88.5m/€100m for Mudryk, who is embroiled in a drugs test fiasco.
